Title:
Three new species of Trichoderma with hyaline ascospores from
China
Keywords:
Hypocreales, phylogeny, RPB2, se- quence analyses,
taxonomy, TEF1-a
Abstract:
Collections of Trichoderma having hyaline ascospores from
different areas of China were examined. Using combined analyses of
morphologi- cal data, culture characters and phylogenetic infor- mation
based on rDNA sequences of partial nuc translation elongation factor 1-a
encoding gene (TEF1-a) and the gene encoding the second largest nuc RNA
polymerase subunit (RPB2), three new species, Trichoderma applanatum, T.
oligosporum and T. sinoluteum, were discovered and are described.
Trichoderma applanatum produces continuous flat to pulvinate, white to
cream stromata with dense orange or pale brown ostioles, and simple
acremonium-like to verticillium-like conidiophores, belongs to the
Hypocreanum clade and is closely related to T. decipiens. Trichoderma
oligosporum forms reddish brown stromata with a downy surface, hyaline
conidia and gliocladium-like conidiophores, and is closely related to
but distinct from T. crystalligenum in the Psychrophila clade.
Trichoderma sinoluteum, as a member of the Polysporum clade, is
characterized by pale yellow stromata, white pustulate conidiomata,
pachybasium-like conidiophores, and hyaline conidia. Differences between
the new species and their close relatives are discussed.
